title: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language): December useR Meetup  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language)
description:
We have 3 confirmed lightning presentations for December's meetup!
Additional details to be provided.

Talk 1:
Title: Advancing pre-clinical research with R and cloud computing
Presented by Nobal Dhruw, Sabu George, Shashank Jatav

Abstract:
R has been the popular tool of choice for performing bioinformatics analysis by researchers in the drug discovery space given the availability of many open-source packages and libraries in the public domain. These open-source tools enable researchers to analyze and generate insights from their biomedical data. Typically, the analysis and the consumption of insights is done via an interactive web interface powered by shiny, an R package to build web-apps. However, our experience developing traditional shiny apps for biological (omics) data analysis, has exposed to us problems related to the handling of voluminous datasets, and the associated computationally expensive jobs, typical characteristics of biological data. Then, there is also the problem of workflow customisability, as a shiny app is often built to cater to one specific use case. But it is often desired to have a certain degree of flexibility and customisability in-built into the system, which would allow the end-users themselves to create their own workflow by stitching together the atomic components. Here, we describe how we have leveraged cloud computing services to mitigate these issues and create an infrastructure which would enable the bioinformaticians to perform data analysis in an easy and intuitive manner, and at the same time giving them the liberty to package their R code as a custom component, without having to worry about how to make their code production-ready. Our infrastructure platform manages the allocation of machine resources required to execute the component.

Bio:
Nobal Dhruw (Sr. Data Scientist, Elucidata)
Sabu George (Tech Lead, Elucidata)
Shashank Jatav (Sr. Data Scientist, Elucidata)

Talk #2:
R and SQLite: A Winning Combination
Presented by Bryan Cafferky

R is an awesome data analysis language. SQLite is the most popular relational database on the planet. Why not use them together? In this presentation, Bryan will explain how persisting data to a SQLite database with R can greatly enhance your data analysis and machine learning development. Best of all, it's easy to use. Join us for this fun and practical presentation.

Bio:
Bryan is the author of the book Master Azure Databricks Step by Step available on Amazon and the creator of a popular data engineering and artificial intelligence YouTube training channel. He had decades of experience in multiple industries and was a Microsoft Worldwide Learning Data Science content creator. He authored Pro PowerShell for Database Developers published by Apress. Bryan is currently a Data and AI consultant and frequently speaks on technical subjects. His a past Microsoft Data Platform and Cloud MVP. He leads the Rhode Island Business Intelligence Virtual User Group https://www.meetup.com/The-RI-Microsoft-BIUG/. Bryan's YouTube channel can be found at https://www.youtube.com/c/BryanCafferky

Talk #3
What's new in dbplyr 2.0.0?!
Presented by Mara Averick

Bio:
Mara is the tidyverse developer advocate at RStudio

title: CopenhagenR - useR Group: Bayesian Multilevel Modeling with {brms}  [Virtual] , Denmark, Europe
description:
The {brms} package provides an interface to fit Bayesian generalized (non-)linear multivariate multilevel models using Stan, a C++ package for performing full Bayesian inference (see https://mc-stan.org/). The formula syntax is very similar to that of the {lme4} package to provide a familiar and simple interface for performing regression analyses. A wide range of response distributions are supported, allowing users to fit ‚Äì among others ‚Äì linear, robust linear, count data, survival, response times, ordinal, zero-inflated, and even self-defined mixture models all in a multilevel context. Further modeling options include non-linear and smooth terms, auto-correlation structures, censored data, missing value imputation, and quite a few more. In addition, all parameters of the response distribution can be predicted in order to perform distributional regression. Multivariate models, i.e., models with multiple response variables, can be fit as well. Prior specifications are flexible and explicitly encourage users to apply prior distributions that reflect their beliefs. Model fits can easily be assessed and compared with posterior predictive checks, cross-validation, and Bayes factors.

[Bio]
Paul is a statistician currently working as an Independent Junior Research Group Leader at the Cluster of Excellence SimTech at the University of Stuttgart (Germany). He is the author of the R package {brms} and member of the Stan Development Team. Previously, he studied Psychology and Mathematics at the Universities of M√ºnster and Hagen (Germany) and did his PhD in M√ºnster about optimal design and Bayesian data analysis. He has also worked as a Postdoctoral researcher at the Department of Computer Science at Aalto University (Finland).

[About]
This event is organized by the Oslo useR! Group and will be co-hosted by the Sk√•ne useR! Group, the Copenhagen useR! Group, and the Stockholm useR! Group.

title: Montreal R User Group: [Webinar] Serverless for ML Inference on Kubernetes: Panacea or Folly?  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
Register here: https://hubs.li/H0BvQkk0

As providers of an end-to-end MLOps platform, we find that autoscaling ML inference is a frequent customer ask. Recently, serverless computing has been touted as the panacea for elastic compute that can provide flexibility and lower operating costs. However, for ML, the need to precisely define hardware configurations and long warm-up times of certain ML models exacerbate the limitations of serverless. To provide the best solution to our customers, we have run extensive benchmarking experiments comparing the performance of serverless and traditional computing for inference workloads running on Kubernetes (with KubeFlow and with the ModelDB MLOps Toolkit). Our experiments have spanned a variety of model types, data modalities, hardware, and workloads. In this talk, we present the results from our benchmarking study and provide a guide to architect your own k8s-based ML inference system.

Register here: https://hubs.li/H0BvQkk0

title: Oslo useR! Group: [Online] Bayesian Multilevel Modelling with {brms}  [Virtual] , Norway, Europe
description:
[Abstract]
The {brms} package provides an interface to fit Bayesian generalized (non-)linear multivariate multilevel models using Stan, a C++ package for performing full Bayesian inference (see https://mc-stan.org/). The formula syntax is very similar to that of the {lme4} package to provide a familiar and simple interface for performing regression analyses. A wide range of response distributions are supported, allowing users to fit ‚Äì among others ‚Äì linear, robust linear, count data, survival, response times, ordinal, zero-inflated, and even self-defined mixture models all in a multilevel context. Further modeling options include non-linear and smooth terms, auto-correlation structures, censored data, missing value imputation, and quite a few more. In addition, all parameters of the response distribution can be predicted in order to perform distributional regression. Multivariate models, i.e., models with multiple response variables, can be fit as well. Prior specifications are flexible and explicitly encourage users to apply prior distributions that reflect their beliefs. Model fits can easily be assessed and compared with posterior predictive checks, cross-validation, and Bayes factors.

[Bio]
Paul is a statistician currently working as an Independent Junior Research Group Leader at the Cluster of Excellence SimTech at the University of Stuttgart (Germany). He is the author of the R package {brms} and member of the Stan Development Team. Previously, he studied Psychology and Mathematics at the Universities of M√ºnster and Hagen (Germany) and did his PhD in M√ºnster about optimal design and Bayesian data analysis. He has also worked as a Postdoctoral researcher at the Department of Computer Science at Aalto University (Finland).

[About]
This event is organized by the Oslo useR! Group and will be co-hosted by the Sk√•ne useR! Group (https://www.meetup.com/Skane-R-User-Group/), the Copenhagen useR! Group (https://www.meetup.com/CopenhagenR-useR-Group/), and the Stockholm useR! Group (https://www.meetup.com/StockholmR/).

title: Atlanta R Users Group: Introduction to Predictive Learning with R , United States, US/Canada
description:
Steve Pittard has gracefully offered to help us get this group rebooted. He will be delivering a talk on predictive learning in R via Zoom. Please join us next week!

Overview:

Many researchers and analysts (and those who aspires to be) have an awareness of Machine Learning methods but lack a general framework for the implementation, interpretation, and deployment of predictive models. This session motivates use of the caret package which provides a streamlined interface to over 200 different methods used in Machine Learning. The caret package eases the comparison of various models in a reproducible way. The session will also include a demonstration of popular ‚ÄúAuto Machine Learning‚Äù services that heuristically select models appropriate for the data.

Mr. Pittard develops Data Science coursework for Biostatistics and Bioinformatics. He is the recent recipient of a US Patent for OmicSeq, a genomic search engine which can be used to identify genes as indicators of cancer treatment protocols. He is a contributor to the upcoming Springer book entitled Computational Methods and Data Analysis for Metabolomics.
When: Dec 17,[masked]:00 PM Eastern Time (US and Canada)

Register in advance for this meeting:
https://zoom.us/meeting/register/tJUqduGopjIvHNJlmDq1-Ys2Q_I0zB1UBeqI

title: Bay Area useR Group (R Programming Language): December BARUG Meetup  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: Bay Area useR Group (R Programming Language)
description:
Come join us for the last BARUG meetup of 2020. Our speakers include long time BARUG members and frequent speakers John-Mark Agosta and Norm Matloff, and first time speaker Paromita Dubey, Stanford Statistics Department Stein Fellow.

Agenda:
5:00 Networking
5:30 Announcements
5:40 John-Mark Agosta: The "PCA Trick": Separating normal and abnormal time series components
6:00 Paromita Dubey: Modeling time varying random objects and dynamic networks
6:30 Norm Matloff: The Notion of Double Descent

############
John-mark Agosta
The "PCA Trick": Separating normal and abnormal time series components

Principal Component Analysis (PCA) is best known for its feature generation ability, to find a subspace where most of the feature variance lives. Alternately, when applied to concurrent time-series, it is capable of segregating data into common periodic versus occasional anomalous components.

We show how this applies to detection of anomalies in VM performance time series, increasing the probability of detection while decreasing spurious alerts two orders of magnitude better than current na√Øve thresholding methods. We demonstrate this on data of incidents of known VM degradation, using conventional hold-out validation to optimize true positive and false positive rates.

############
Paromita Dubey
Modeling time varying random objects and dynamic networks

Functional Data Analysis tools have been widely studied for samples of curves that take values in a Hilbert space. Samples of dynamic or time-varying networks and other random object data such as time-varying probability distributions are increasingly encountered in modern data analysis.

However, common methods for time-varying data such as functional data analysis are infeasible when observations are time courses of networks or other complex non-Euclidean random objects that are elements of general metric spaces. In such spaces, only pairwise distances between the data objects are available and a strong limitation is that one cannot carry out arithmetic operations due to the lack of an algebraic structure.

We combat this complexity by a generalized notion of mean trajectory taking values in the object space. For this, we adopt pointwise Fr√©chet means and then construct pointwise distance trajectories between the individual time courses and the estimated Fr√©chet mean trajectory, thus representing the time-varying objects and networks by functional data. Functional principal component analysis of these distance trajectories can reveal interesting features of dynamic networks and object time courses and is useful for downstream analysis.

Our approach also makes it possible to study the empirical dynamics of time-varying objects, including dynamic regression to the mean or explosive behavior over time. We demonstrate desirable asymptotic properties of sample based estimators for suitable population targets under mild assumptions. The utility of the proposed methodology is illustrated with both dynamic network and time-varying distribution data.

#####
Norm Matloff
The Notion of Double Descent

The notion of double descent, which has come into prominence in the last few years, is something I regard as genuinely new and very relevant, shedding important light on the central issue of model overfitting.

In this talk, I‚Äôll explain the idea, and illustrate it using code from my regtools R package. (Have a look at Norm's Post (https://matloff.wordpress.com/2020/11/11/the-notion-of-double-descent/#comments) to prepare for the talk.

title: Sydney Users of  R Forum (SURF): AlphaZetta Global Analytics Summit - Sydney 2021, Australia, Australia
description:
Registration is required on the AlphaZetta site - links below.

The AlphaZetta Global Analytics Summit is a unique conference experience, built around experts sharing their knowledge, use cases, best practice and having time for meaningful interactions. It is not vendor driven - there‚Äôs no booths or selling and no big crowds - we expect only ~150 attendees. The summit provides insightful presentations, fantastic networking and discussion time at great value!

We are delighted that the next GAS will be held in Sydney on Friday 5th March at the Manly Pacific Hotel. Further details including the agenda can be found here ( https://alphazetta.ai/event/global-analytics-summit-sydney-2020/ ).

The day starts with presentations on the current state of the analytics market and key trends to look for in the future. The second section is about inspiring attendees with keynotes from Volt Bank on creating a new business based on data and analytics and from Raiffeisen Bank on building an analytics team to provide true value to the whole organisation.

The afternoon focuses on innovation and implementation. We have presentations from some of Australia‚Äôs exciting startups (Volt, Adgile Media, Self Assured Pty Ltd) who are using analytics to disrupt their markets. To close, we will hear a keynote on how to deliver analytics and increase AI adoption.

The Summit venue is the Novotel Pacific, Manly which is right on the ocean beach, with lunch and dinner included.

All up, at just $350 for standard tickets, it‚Äôs a conference like no other!

title: Barcelona R User Group: Online event organised by: Portsmouth R (Topic: COVID analysis)  [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
description:
Hello everyone! We would like to invite you to join a fellow R group event organised online. Please see event details below:

Portsmouth R

This will be our first virtual meet-up! Please join us on-line for our Covid Special. We have two speakers lined up who will each tell us about what they have been doing during the pandemic.

Dr Rich Tyler works in Public Health for West Sussex County Council. Rich is a very experienced R user who has used his skills to process data received from multiple sources for the reports he needs to produce frequently.

Dr Ina Kostakis is Research Fellow in the Centre for Healthcare Modelling and Informatics at the University of Portsmouth. Ina is an experienced modeller but relatively new to R. However, she has picked up the skills quickly and is going to share some recently published research: the performance of the National Early Warning Score (NEWS) & NEWS2 in patients with SARS-CoV-2.

We plan to start at 6.30pm and the event will last approximately an hour.

title: Campus useR Group Frankfurt: January meeting: Academic writing with R  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
We hit 2021 running with a session on academic writing with R.
There are layers to unpack: RMarkdown, LaTeX, Citations, .*down$ packages and custom templates... In a freestyle format, we share our workflows, questions, ideas, best practices and train-wreck experiences with compiling sleek scientific papers from R. What's keeping *you* from publishing your reproducible research with R?

As always, useRs of all walks of life and at all levels of expertise are invited to participate. Learning R is not a competition. Come join us!

title: R-Ladies Philly: Introduction to R dashboard development with Shiny Dashboard  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
This introduction to Shiny Dashboards is for people who are interested in creating multi-Shiny app dashboards in R using the ‚Äúshinydashboard‚Äù package. Topics such as reactivity, appearance (i.e. dashboard themes), profiling, and deployment will be covered. Over the course of the workshop, users will learn how to go from a raw data file to a working multi-app dashboard that can be updated based on user input.

The workshop will be suitable for beginner to intermediate R users or for those who are new to dashboard and app development. Former experience with Shiny is not necessary for this workshop. Some familiarity with R and/or data visualization methods would be helpful and assumed but not required, so novice users are encouraged to attend.

Speaker

Anastasia Lucas is a data analyst working in biomedical informatics and computational genomics research at the University of Pennsylvania‚Äôs Perelman School of Medicine. Her work in R mainly focuses on statistical analysis, package development, and data visualization.

- Lydia Gabriela Speyer (University of Edinburgh) - Modelling Dynamic Change in Longitudinal Data

Passcode for the Zoom call will be emailed on the day of the event.

--

R-Ladies is a worldwide organization whose mission is to promote gender diversity in the R community.

A question we often get is "Are men welcome to attend this event?"

As a diversity initiative, the mission of R-Ladies is to achieve proportionate representation by encouraging, inspiring, and empowering people of genders currently underrepresented in the R community. R-Ladies‚Äô primary focus, therefore, is on supporting minority gender R enthusiasts to achieve their programming potential, by building a collaborative global network of R leaders, mentors, learners, and developers to facilitate individual and collective progress worldwide.

**As such, we strongly encourage cis-men who attend this event come as guests of R-Ladies who are minority genders (including but not limited to cis/trans women, trans men, non-binary, genderqueer, agender).**

All attendees are strongly encouraged to review the R-Ladies Code of Confuct (https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct) and must abide by it.

title: R-Ladies Rotterdam: Microbenchmarking: measuring and improving R code performance  [Virtual] , Netherlands, Europe
description:
Welcome!

We are so thrilled to have Semiramis Castro as our speaker in our last event of the year. In this session we will discuss the core concepts about Microbenchmarking - that is, how to measure and improve performance of R code. We will base this session on chapter 23 and 24 of the Advanced R book (https://adv-r.hadley.nz/) by Hadley Wickham.

About R-Ladies NL book club
----------------------
This is the grand finale of a series of events based on Hadley Wickham's Advanced R book, hosted by R-Ladies chapters of the Netherlands.

You can find the slides and materials from previous sessions at: https://github.com/rladiesnl/book_club

About Semiramis
----------------------
Semiramis is a software developer/data scientist who codes mainly in R and Python. She's a recent PhD graduate from the National Autonomous University of Mexico with a focus on genomics of pathogenic bacteria and antibiotic resistance. Among the bacteria she studied are the emerging pathogen Acinetobacter haemolyticus and the deadly Acinetobacter baumannii.

----------------------

title: R-Ladies Amsterdam: Automatic & Explainable Machine Learning in R with H2O  [Virtual] , Netherlands, Europe
description:
Hi, everybody!
We hope that you and your family are doing well. We are super excited to have Erin, co-founder of R-Ladies global, founder of the Women in Machine Learning and Data Science and Chief Machine Learning Scientist at H2O.ai to bring you a workshop on Automatic and Explainable Machine Learning in R with H2O!

DESCRIPTION
----------------------

H2O is an open source, distributed machine learning platform is designed to scale to very large datasets. H2O AutoML provides an easy-to-use interface which automates data pre-processing, training and tuning a large selection of candidate models from a single function, `h2o.automl()`. The result of the AutoML run is a "leaderboard" of H2O models, which can be then be explained automatically using the H2O Explainability interface.

The models can be explained individually, and also compared as a group and both global (model-wise) and local (row-wise) explainations are available. The `h2o.explain()` function generates a list of explanations ‚Äì individual units of explanation such as a Partial Dependence plot or a Variable Importance plot. Most of the explanations are visual ‚Äì these plots can also be created by individual utility functions outside the `h2o.explain()` function. The visualization engine used in the R interface is the ggplot2 package and in Python, we use matplotlib.

R code with a full demo will be provided, which can be used to automatically train and explain models on your own dataset.

PROGRAMME
----------------------
[masked] Virtual Welcome
19.05- 20.30 Talk & Q&A

ABOUT ERIN
----------------------
https://www.linkedin.com/in/erin-ledell/
Erin LeDell is the Chief Machine Learning Scientist at H2O.ai, the company that produces the open source, distributed machine learning platform, H2O. At H2O.ai, she leads the H2O AutoML project and her current research focus is automated machine learning. Before joining H2O.ai, she was the Principal Data Scientist at Wise.io (acquired by GE) and Marvin Mobile Security (acquired by Veracode), the founder of DataScientific, Inc. and a software engineer. She is also founder of the Women in Machine Learning and Data Science (WiMLDS) organization (wimlds.org) and co-founder of R-Ladies Global (rladies.org). Erin received her Ph.D. in Biostatistics with a Designated Emphasis in Computational Science and Engineering from University of California, Berkeley and has a B.S. and M.A. in Mathematics.

We will have an exciting presentation from Lucy D'Agostino McGowan (https://www.lucymcgowan.com) an Assistant Professor in Statistics, Wake Forest University. She will give a presentation on two R packages: matahari (https://github.com/jhudsl/matahari) and tidycode (https://lucymcgowan.github.io/tidycode/). The matahari package is a simple package for tidy logging of everything you type into the R console. title: R-Ladies Washington D.C.: Books In Bars - Algorithms of Oppression  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Spend Friday night discussing Algorithms of Oppression (https://www.bookdepository.com/Algorithms-Oppression-Safiya-Umoja-Noble/9781479837243).

A revealing look at how negative biases against women of color are embedded in search engine results and algorithms

Run a Google search for "black girls"-what will you find? "Big Booty" and other sexually explicit terms are likely to come up as top search terms. But, if you type in "white girls," the results are radically different. The suggested porn sites and un-moderated discussions about "why black women are so sassy" or "why black women are so angry" presents a disturbing portrait of black womanhood in modern society.

In Algorithms of Oppression, Safiya Umoja Noble challenges the idea that search engines like Google offer an equal playing field for all forms of ideas, identities, and activities. Data discrimination is a real social problem; Noble argues that the combination of private interests in promoting certain sites, along with the monopoly status of a relatively small number of Internet search engines, leads to a biased set of search algorithms that privilege whiteness and discriminate against people of color, specifically women of color.

Through an analysis of textual and media searches as well as extensive research on paid online advertising, Noble exposes a culture of racism and sexism in the way discoverability is created online. As search engines and their related companies grow in importance-operating as a source for email, a major vehicle for primary and secondary school learning, and beyond-understanding and reversing these disquieting trends and discriminatory practices is of utmost importance.

An original, surprising and, at times, disturbing account of bias on the internet, Algorithms of Oppression contributes to our understanding of how racism is created, maintained, and disseminated in the 21st century.

PS Please contact the organizer if you need support finding the book.

title: Canberra R Users Group: AlphaZetta Global Analytics Summit - Sydney 2021, Australia, Australia
description:
Registration is required on the AlphaZetta site - links below.

The AlphaZetta Global Analytics Summit is a unique conference experience, built around experts sharing their knowledge, use cases, best practice and having time for meaningful interactions. It is not vendor driven - there‚Äôs no booths or selling and no big crowds - we expect only ~150 attendees. The summit provides insightful presentations, fantastic networking and discussion time at great value!

We are delighted that the next GAS will be held in Sydney on Friday 5th March at the Manly Pacific Hotel. Further details including the agenda can be found here ( https://alphazetta.ai/event/global-analytics-summit-sydney-2020/ ).

The day starts with presentations on the current state of the analytics market and key trends to look for in the future. The second section is about inspiring attendees with keynotes from Volt Bank on creating a new business based on data and analytics and from Raiffeisen Bank on building an analytics team to provide true value to the whole organisation.

The afternoon focuses on innovation and implementation. We have presentations from some of Australia‚Äôs exciting startups (Volt, Adgile Media, Self Assured Pty Ltd) who are using analytics to disrupt their markets. To close, we will hear a keynote on how to deliver analytics and increase AI adoption.

The Summit venue is the Novotel Pacific, Manly which is right on the ocean beach, with lunch and dinner included.

All up, at just $350 for standard tickets, it‚Äôs a conference like no other!

Here‚Äôs a video clip to highlight all of the above! (https://youtu.be/YKnFo0thEMM)

Presenters Include:
Steve Weston - Co-Founder and CEO, Volt Bank
Stephen Brobst - AlphaZetta Advisory Board; Chief Technology Officer, Teradata; TDWI Fellow
Felipe Flores - Founder, Data Futurology; GM Data Science and Analytics, Liberty Financial
Martin Endrizal, BI Application Operations Manager, Vodafone Czech Republic
Markus Lochner - Head of Group Digital Solutions, Raiffeisen Bank International
Tony Ohlsson - Founder, AlphaZetta; Chief Analytics Officer, Volt Bank

PLEASE DO NOT RSVP ON MEETUP.COM.
Further details including the agenda can be found here ( https://alphazetta.ai/event/global-analytics-summit-sydney-2020/ )
Tickets are available here ( https://www.eventbrite.sg/e/global-analytics-summit-sydney-2020-tickets-85943209453 )

title: R-Ladies RTP: Introduction to R Packages for Bayesian Models  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
At this virtual meetup, R-Ladies RTP member Melissa Wong (she/her), will introduce some R packages (rstanarm, rethinking, and possibly brms) for Bayesian models that are a bit easier to get started with than rstan. Melissa will include examples of both a simple linear regression and a semi-parametric regression in all packages, and talk about what she found to be a beginner-friendly path to work up to using rstan directly.

Melissa's Bio: I'm a Senior Engineer with The Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory. I started my career as a software and systems engineer. Since finishing my M.S. in Statistics I've become interested in learning more about Bayesian methods and causal inference.

Special thanks to Melissa for suggesting, developing, and leading this meetup!

What do I bring?
Please login to Zoom using a laptop or computer with the capabilities to run R and RStudio. We encourage attendees to install or update their versions of R and RStudio as well as their R packages. To update your R Packages in RStudio go to Tools > "Check for package updates...". Here are links to free downloads for R (https://cran.r-project.org/) and RStudio (https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/#download). Downloading and installing both of these programs before this meetup will help us keep on schedule and make sure you learn the most you can while at the meetup event.

Who is this event for?
Beginners are welcome and encouraged to join this event but please install the most recent version of both R and RStudio on your laptop before attending this meetup event. See information above for instructions.

Where will it take place?
**Please join us online via Zoom.** A link to join will be provided when you RSVP.

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please introduce yourself to an organizer.

title: R-Ladies Seattle: Our Year in Data  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Join us for lunch time lightning talks exploring our favorite data visualizations of 2020. Sign up to present here (https://forms.gle/iANLN28nNvZCwV1q8).

Many of us participate in TidyTuesday, a weekly social data project in R (https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday). Present your favorite project from this year's TidyTuesday's data sets, or another data set you found interesting in 2020.

If you want to learn more about TidyTuesday or get help with a project, we'll host "office hours" the week before on our R-Ladies Slack channel. Please message the meeting host if you need to be invited to the Slack channel.

Office hours: 12-1pm on December 8th and 9th.

title: Taiwan R User Group / MLDM Monday: MLDM Monday @ ‰∏âÂâµËÇ≤Êàê | Recommendation Systems in Real Life, Taiwan, Asia
group: Taiwan R User Group / MLDM Monday
description:
Êú¨Ê¨°ËÅöÊúÉÂú∞ÈªûÊñº‰∏âÂâµËÇ≤ÊàêÂü∫ÈáëÊúÉÔºà11FÔºâÂ†¥Âú∞

Ë¨õÈ°åÔºöRecommendation Systems in Real Life

Ë¨õÈ°å‰ªãÁ¥πÔºö
Recommendation systems are used everywhere nowadays. This talk will discuss how differently recommendation systems are researched and applied in academia and industry, and challenges one might face or criteria one might care about when building recommendation systems. In real life, the job of a recommendation algorithm is not to be very predictive of past held-out interactions but is to be predictive of future interactions. What is really important is its performance after being deployed, which is in the future. In addition, users change over time, items change over time, even the system around the recommendation algorithm is going to change over time, which might impact things and need to be considered. In this talk, we will talk about how we tackle some of these challenges and recent trends in personalization at Netflix.

Ë¨õËÄÖ‰ªãÁ¥πÔºö
Ko-Jen (Mark) Hsiao is a senior research scientist at Netflix, where he researches and implements innovative algorithms to optimize Netflix's core personalization. He has extensive experiences in applying machine learning at scale, building and A/B testing ranking and recommendation systems. Before he joined Netflix, he was a data scientist at Whisper, an anonymous social network app with over 30 million monthly active users. He developed and implemented several end-to-end machine learning systems used by the company. He obtained his PhD from the University of Michigan, where he focused on combining disparate information for machine learning applications.

title: R-Ladies Boston: Tips and Tricks for Interactive HTML Tables with R  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Join us as Sharon Machlis (https://www.machlis.com/) shares her excitement about all the things you can do with interactive tables! (like put tiny, tiny plots into them!)

[Zoom link TBA]

About Sharon

Sharon is equally at home analyzing data, coding tools for journalists, and writing about technology. She is currently director of editorial data & analytics at IDG Communications, publisher of tech Web sites including Computerworld, CIO, PCWorld, and Macworld.

She has worked on data projects such as analyzing tens of thousands of tech visa applications. She has also taught both R and general data visualization at ProPublica, Investigative Reporters and Editors' Computer Assisted Reporting conferences, Boston University workshops, American Society of Business Press Editors webinars, and a national Journalism and Women Symposium.

She was previously executive editor, data & analytics at Computerworld, where she won the 2014 ASBPE national gold award for impact/investigative online excellence (see story) and the 2014 and 2017 ASBPE national golds for best how-to article (see 2014 and 2017 winners).

Sharon holds an Extra-class ham radio license and was honored by the Association of Radio Amateurs of Bosnia & Herzegovina "for extraordinary contribution to transmitting humanitarian messages of the citizens of Bosnia-Herzegovina" during the[masked] war.

Sharon's other hobbies include photography, travel, hiking, snowshoeing, and classical piano. And, she's somewhat obsessed with the R programming language.
